actions.name: Emergency Descent (If needed)
actions.action: TO A SAFE ALTITUDE CONSISTENT WITH TERRAIN

actions.name: If sufficient runway remains for a complete stop:
If sufficient altitude has been gained to attempt a restart:
If power is not regained, proceed with power off landing.
LEFT/RIGHT MAG Switches
actions.action: Turn OFF then ON one at a time

actions.name: Land as soon as practical and investigate cause of power loss.
If power is not restored prepare for power-off landing.
Landing Pattern
actions.action: ESTABLISH 1000 FT ABOVE FIELD AT DOWNWIND POSITION

actions.name: Indications: Master Warning, Triple Chime, Flashing Red Oil Pressure Indication
If accompanied by high oil temperature, land as soon as possible.
If accompanied by normal oil temperature, land as soon as possible.
If possible, always retain glide capability to the selected landing area in case of total engine failure.
Indications: Master Warning, Triple Chime, Flashing Red Oil Temperature Indication
Land as soon as possible and investigate the problem. Prepare for power off Landing.
If possible, always retain glide capability to the selected landing area in case of total engine failure.

If normal engine operation and fuel flow is not immediately re-established, or if the engine quits, the electric fuel pump should be turned off. The lack of fuel flow indication could indicate a leak in the fuel system, or fuel exhaustion. Land at the nearest suitable airport as soon as possible and have the cause investigated.
If caused by fuel depletion in one tank:
If caused by engine driven fuel pump failure:
Indication: Master Warning, Triple Chime L FUEL QTY or R FUEL QTY
Avoid unusual attitudes such as prolonged slips towards the low quantity tank as this will decrease the time remaining prior to fuel starvation.
If one tank has low fuel quantity:
If both tanks have low fuel quantity:
FUEL Selector
actions.action: ALTERNATE TANKS TO MAINTAIN FUEL SUPPLY TO ENGINE

actions.name: Indication: Master Warning, Triple Chime ALTR FAIL
The ALTR circuit breaker should not be opened manually when the alternator is functioning properly
NON ESS BUS Circuit Breaker (Row 1, Col. 1)
Indication: Single Chime, EMERG BATT ON
The VOLTS indication on the EIS window automatically changes to the emergency bus voltage (E VOLTS) when operating exclusively on the emergency bus.
Cooling air for PFD, GIA1 and the transponder will be lost when operating exclusively on the emergency bus as indicated by th PFD FAN FAIL and AV FAN FAIL advisory CAS messages.
Approximately 30 minutes of electrical power is available.
Indication: Master Warning, Triple Chime, Flashing Red E VOLTS Indication
DISPLAY BACKUP button on audio panel
DME
actions.action: SELECT NAV2 in DME TUNING Window

actions.name: Exit and avoid IFR conditions as soon as practical.

If the PFD fails, the MFD will remain in normal mode. Pushing the DISPLAY BACKUP button on the audio panel allows the MFD to display ADAHRS information but lose the EIS page and certain map functions. The following features will become inoperative if there is a complete loss of PFD functionality: Autopilot, COM1 (yellow x'd but 121.5 MHz remains available), NAV1, GPS1, Traffic
If PFD failure occurs while operating on NAV1 DME, the NAV1 DME information will continue to be available. If the pilot subsequently selects NAV2 DME, NAV1 DME cannot be reselected.
PFD should automatically revert to the reversionary mode display.
Exit and avoid IFR conditions as soon as practical.

The following features will become inoperative if there is a complete loss of MFD functionality: COM2 (yellow x'd but 121.5 MHz remain available), NAV2, GPS2, GDL 69SXM (Garmin Datalink - XM), DME, ADF, ESP

If the GFC700 autopilot was engaged prior to MFD failure, it remain engaged in its current lateral and vertical modes. The modes cannot be changed and if the autopilot is disengaged, it cannot be re-engaged

checklists.title: ADAHRS TOTAL FAILURE ON THE GROUND

actions.name: Indication: Sky/Ground presentation removed, course pointer straight up, yellow-x's and amber text on all air data, attitude and heading indicators.
For partial ADAHRS failures, a yellow-x and amber text will appear over the affected parameter(s).
Indications: Sky/Ground presentation removed, course pointer straight up, yellow-x's and amber text on all air data, attitude and heading indicators.
The following features will become inoperative if there is a complete loss of ADAHRS functionality: Autopilot (including ESP), TAS
For partial ADAHRS failures, a yellow-x and amber text will appear over the affected parameter(s).
Course
actions.action: Set using CRS knob on PFD

checklists.title: ERRONEOUS OR LOSS OF ENGINE AND FUEL DISPLAYS

actions.name: Indication: Yellow-x over affected engine parameter or fuel display.
Erroneous indications may be determined by comparing a display with other system information.
1. Set power based on throttle lever position, engine sound and speed.
2. Monitor other indications to determine the health of the engine.
3. Use known power setting from POH power setting tables for approximate fuel flow values.
4. Use other system information, such as annunciator messages, fuel totalizer quantity and flow, to safely complete the flight.
If indications for any of the following are invalid: All Engine Parameters, VOLTS, ALTR AMPS, BATT AMPS, FUEL QTY
If all GEA parameters are still unavailable, Land as soon as practical.

checklists.title: ERRONEOUS OR LOSS OF WARNING/CAUTION CAS MESSAGES

actions.name: Indication: Yellow-x is shown over the CAS message window or CAS message present when not expected or CAS message not present when expected.
1. If a yellow-x is placed over the CAS message window, monitor engine and airframe indications.
See Section 3.1 of this handbook for a list of CAS Warning, Caution and Advisory messages that may be inoperative.
2. If a CAS message appears that is not expected, treat it as if the condition exists.

3. If an abnormal condition exists but the CAS message has not been activated, use other available information to confirm the condition exists. If it cannot be determined that the condition does not exist, treat the situation as if the condition does exist and take appropriate action.

CAS mesages are inhibited for many parameters on the EIS Display of the MFD. The Master Warning and Master Caution indications and associated chimes are still activated whenever any indicated parameter enters the red or amber bands.
If a yellow-x appears over the CAS message window, Land as soon as practical.
Indication: inability to communicate/receive on COM1 and COM2
If power is lost to the audio panel a fail-safe communications path becomes available between the pilot's headset/microphone and COM1.
Exit and avoid IFR conditions as soon as practical.
Indication: Amber 'DR' annunciation on HSI, Amber 'DR' superimposed over airplane symbol on moving map.
Navigation
actions.action: Use alternate source of navigation (ILS, LOC, VOR, DME, ADF)

actions.name: If no alternative navigation sources are available:
Dead Reckoning (DR) Mode - Active when the airplane is greater than 30 NM from the destination airport in flightplan.
Navigation
actions.action: Use the airplane symbol and magenta course line on the MAP display and amber CDI on the HSI.

actions.name: Information normally derived from GPS turns amber and becomes more inaccurate over time. Amber CDI dissapears after 20 minutes.

DR mode uses heading, airspeed and last known GPS position to estimate the airplanes current position. All maps with an airplane show a ghosted airplane and a 'DR' label. Traffic Information System (TIS) and Traffic Advisory System (TAS) are not dependant on GPS information. The position of displayed traffic relative to the airplane symbol on the map is still accurate.
Loss of Integrity (LOI) Mode - Active when GPS integrity is insufficient for the current phase of flight.
Navigation
actions.action: Crosscheck / use other navigation sources as required

actions.name: All information derived from GPS or DR is removed from the displays. The airplane symbol is removed from all maps. The map will remain centered at the last known position. 'NO GPS POSITION' is shown in the center of the map. TAWS and TAS are inoperative.
Indication: CAS Advisory, Single Chime, AV FAN FAIL and/or PFD FAN FAIL and/or MFD FAN FAIL
If Failure occurs on ground: Do not fly until issue is resolved.
If failure occurs in flight: Fix issue prior to next flight.
When any of these CAS messages illuminate, it is possible to exceed the manufacturer's specified temperature limits for the effected equipment.
Indication: Amber VOR, VAPP, GPS, BC, LOC or GS flashing on PFD
If a navigation signal is lost while the autopilot is tracking it, the autopilot will roll the aircraft wings level and default to roll mode (ROL).
If on an instrument approach at the time the navigation signal is lost:
(A second approach may be attempted using other navaids.)
Indication: Master Caution, Double Chime, PITOT HEAT FAIL
Exit and Avoid Instrument Meteorological Conditions.
Indication: Master Warning, Triple Chime, START ENGD
INTENTIONAL SPINS ARE PROHIBITED IN THIS AIRPLANE
Rudder
actions.action: FULL OPPOSITE TO DIRECTION OF ROTATION

actions.name: Control wheel
actions.action: SMOOTH BACK PRESSURE to recover from dive

actions.name: To Close the door in flight:
Side latch (if open)
actions.action: PULL on Armrest While Closing Latch

actions.name: If both upper and side latches are open, the door will trall slightly open and airspeeds will be reduced slightly.
If roughness continues after one minute:
If operation of satisfactory on either MAG, continue on that magneto at reduced power and full RICH mixture to nearest airport.
If possible, always retain glide capability to the selected landing area in case of total engine failure.
Indications: Master Warning, Triple Chime, CO LVL HIGH
If the CO Detector Warning or Caution activates in flight:
Press the CO RST softkey (on the engine page) to reset the CO Detector.
If the Warning or Caution continues:
Shut off the heater, air conditioning or any other opening to the engine compartment.
Open a fresh air source immediately. Don't smoke.
Be sure the source of the contamination is corrected before further flight.

The Amber MFD alert will remain until the CO level drops below 50 parts per million (PPM) by volume of carbon monoxide concentration. Do not recycle the unit through the circuit breaker. A three-minute delay is required for the CO sensor to stabalize after each power-up.
